publicationStmt.p: File created by Evolving Hands project, Newcastle University

div.ab:
Aug
August
21 Baghdad.
Received
24
Sep
September
1921
1921
Darling Father. I've no letter of yours to answer because there's
no post in this week. I'm not only without letters but also without
papers + books. However, thank God, I've got plenty to say.
Wherein, as you'll note I differ from my Chief. I heard a delightful
saying about him the other day quoted from the lips of one of the leading
notables of Basrah. "Wallahi!" he observed " Sir Percy Cox
has forty ears + only one tongue." I must tell you another
nice talk about the Coxes. You know he is a great naturalist. He is making
a collection of all Mesopotamian birds - sometimes they arrive dead +
sometimes alive. The last one was alive. It's a huge eagle, not yet
in its grown up plumage but for all that the largest fowl you've set eyes
on. It lives on a perch on the shady side of the house + it eats bats,
mainly. These bats are netted for it in the dusk when they obligingly
fly across the river + over Sir Percy's garden wall. But the
eagle likes to eat them in the morning, so the long-suffering Lady
Cox keeps them in a tin in the ice chest, + if ever you've
heard before of an eagle that lives on iced bat you'll please
inform me.
And since I'm telling you stories I must tell you one about the
Naqib. It hangs on to what I was relating to you last week on
the subject of al Damakratiyah. It was the Naqib to his huge
delight - he's by every instinct an aristocrat + an autocrat if
ever there was one - who gave currency to the word by announcing in the Council that Faisal
should be king of a constitutional democratic state. He did
this with his tongue in his cheek, you understand, in order to
catch the public. The other day a
Shammar Tribe descended from the ancient Yemeni tribe of Tayy.
shaikh Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
up from
Hail drops in to call. "Are you a Damakrati?" says the
Naqib. "Wallahi, no!" says the Shammari, slightly offended.
"I'm not a Magrati. What is it?" "Well" says the
Naqib, enjoying himself thoroughly, "I'm shaikh of the
Damakratiyah, the Democrats." "I take refuge in God!"
replied the shaikh, feeling he had gone wrong somewhere.
"If you're the shaikh of the Magratiyah, then I must be

then I must be one of them, for I'm altogether in your
service But what is it?" "Damakratiyah" says the
Naqib "is equality. There's no big man + no little - all
are alike + equal." With that the bewildered
Shammari Tribe descended from the ancient Yemeni tribe of Tayy.
plumped onto solid ground. "God is my witness." said he,
seeing his tribal authority slipping from him "if that's it,
I'm not a Magrati."
Well, now to the History of the 'Iraq.
Last Monday was the first day of the 'Id al Fitr, the Feast
of Sacrifice, which is the great occasion of the Moslem year.
It lasts four mortal days. At 7 a.m. on Monday, Mr Cornwallis
+ I set out on a round of calls. We went first to the Naqib
+ found him in the highest spirits, surrounded, by the way,
by Shammar shaikhs from up Mosul direction. We had a
very hilarious quarter of an hour with him. Then we called on
five ministers, two of whom were providentially out; then on
Faisal, but we stayed only two minutes since there were thousands
of people waiting to come in who were being kept out while
we sat with him. Then on 'Abdul Majid Shawi who was out,
+ then on old Yusuf Sawaidi whom I had never called on
before. It's nice, isn't it, to make a sensation when you come
into a room. We did. And I don't wonder they were pleased to
see us for the rest of the roomful were the most shoddy little
people, only three of whom I had ever seen before - + two.
of those were 'Aqail, the desert merchants, whom I know
because it's my business to know them for the news they bring,
but no one can say they are hoffähig. The company was
the clearest indication of where Yusuf Suwaidi now stands.
He's a spent bullet, or rather he's a broken drum, for he
never was more than an empty drum, poor old thing.
Then we went to the Persian consul + then to another minister
who was out, + at last to the office at 9.45. It's rather
fun. But it wasn't over, for I had to go to tea that evening

2 with the wife of the Persian Consul who had heard of my
morning visit + wanted me to come + 'Id with her
too. Mrs Garbett + I went together, + I'm sorry to say
I was rather short with an Austrian woman who was
there - not because she was Austrian but because she
was tiresome. But one shouldn't be short with any one
especially when they're married to one of of our medical
officers. Perhaps it was partly because I had paid so many calls.
That afternoon Faisal called on the Naqib + asked him
to form his first cabinet - a very, very wise move. Who
so pleased as the Naqib! he's embarking on a promising
political career at the age of 77. Good, isn't it.
On Tuesday we had a terrific tea in the house of Saiyid Ja'far
'Ataifah, Mayor of Kadhimain - you remember we went to tea
in his garden. It happened this way: old Saiyid Ja'far has
stood by us like a man, trembling in his shoes + all the
braver for that. Consequently the
scallywags scalliwags
of
mujtahids An original authority of Islamic law.
have cold shouldered him + though Faisal has been twice to
Kadhimain, he has not been allowed to come within sight of
Saiyid Ja'far 's house. He came to me + said that his honour
was broken. I said "Tosh - you trot round to Sidi Faisal +
ask him to tea + I'll ask the High Commissioner + the
G.O.C in C.
General Officer Commanding in Chief " Faisal played up; Sir Aylmer took me;
the Coxes brought one another + Faisal brought his
ADC aide-de-camps.
Saiyid Ja'far played up too. I have not yet been privileged
to see so many cakes + fruits on one table, + after
tea he presented Faisal with a gold watch, a diamond
ring, a fur coat + some Persian shawls + rugs. That's
what you do it seems, when you entertain kings.
On
Wed. Wednesday
I gave a dinner party: Rustam Haidar whom
I love - he is Faisal's secretary - Saiyid Husain Afnan
a young barrister, Muzahim Pachahji by name (the one

who made the speech in English at one tea party
at Basrah) + another barrister whom you don't know
Rauf Beg Chadirji, a pal of mine. Mr Thomson, the
most darling of all my colleagues, came to help. Of
the Arabs there wasn't one who couldn't speak 3
languages well + two spoke five. But we talked Arabic
which was nicest because they talked best in it. And
they did talk well! From beginning to end there wasn't a
moment without quite excellent, sometimes almost
brilliant conversation. And so light in hand, so intimate
with us - I must say I went to bed happy. If
you can preserve that atmosphere, what can't you
do? There was an amusing episode when we talked
about Kirkuk - I told you Kirkuk has rejected Faisal
+ Arab Government. The Arabs are very angry. I hold
the Kirkuklis to be asses, at the same time there's no one
who has so little sympathy for the Nationalism of the man
next below him as the ardent Nationalist. "Have they
the right?" said Muzahim. "Oh yes" said I " Istiqlal
al tamm, complete independence" - it's the catch word
of the extremists here. And Saiyid Husain, fully realizing
the humour of the situation, backed me by quoting the idiot
phrase which the extremists of Baghdad - + no one else -
added to the Referendum papers: Cut off from the control
of any one. On that we agreed to leave the handling of
Kirkuk to Sir Percy whom the party unanimously
declared to be the father of wiles. It was then they told
the story about his forty ears.
Next day I had a very interesting morning in the office.
Faisal's presence has brought to Baghdad people I've
always heard of + never seen before - they all come

3
to me for an appointment with Sir Percy. One of these was
'Abdullah Beg ibn Falih Pasha Sa'dun. He is the head of
one of the two branches of the Sa'dun house down Nasiriyah
way. He was with the Turks when I was in Basrah + he
has not been up here since the Occupation. I never saw such
a type of high breeding. He is a little over 6
ft feet , very
slender, but that is rectified by his Arab robes, not
really handsome, but with a face drawn with such
amazing fineness + precision. I shouldn't think he is
worth much - he's almost over-bred; but he's a beautiful
creature to look at. And still more splendid was one
of the shaikhs of the northern
Shammar Tribe descended from the ancient Yemeni tribe of Tayy. , 'Ajil al Yawar.
I had seen him in 1917 when he came in to us. Then he
quarrelled with one of his uncles, whom he rightly
thought we overestimated + drifted off to the Turks. He
came in again when we took Mosul, + drifted off
again, we never quite knew why, but Mr Nalder
had always regretted it + so have I, for from the
first moment I saw him I reckoned him foremost of the Shammar
shaikhs in character + influence. Faisal, with our
concurrence, sent for him, + he came at once. He is 6
ft feet
4
in inches
odd, a proud, more powerful, magnificent creature,
not an ounce of spare flesh on him; hands you would
like to model, not too small but exquisitely shaped. Under
his red kerchief four thick
plaits plats
of black hair fall
down to his breast. Black beard, trimmed short; white +
gold
abba Loose over-garment , white cotton shirt buttoned to the neck + wrists
- that's the picture. He has been several times to see me. Last visit we talked for about an
hour of one thing + another - mostly of his experiences
with the Turks + of the divisions of his tribe - + at the end
when we had become rather intimate, I told him we had
always regretted his going off the second time in 1918 + asked

him why he did it. Generally as he talks he sits loosely in his
chair, his huge figure relaxed + eyelids a little drooped. He
sat up then + turned the flash of his eyes on me. He
said "I'll tell you. It was Leachman. When I came
in at his bidding to Mosul (he was Political
office there) I tried to speak + he bade me be silent,
he told me I was like a woman + that he would give me
no recognition in my tribe.
Khatun Title of nobility; female counterpart to 'khan'. , I'm a shaikh of
the Arabs; I went back to my tribe - what else
could I do? (I must tell you I believe the tale, it's
so exactly like Col. Leachman.) I said "I don't
think you're very like a woman" + the other man who was
there, Shaikh Hasan Sukhail of the
Bani Tamim One of the largest tribes in the Arabian peninsula.
(our friend of
'Aqar Quf ) laughed + added "Not so very like."
Then I said " 'Ajil, I can't force you to do anything
but I can give you advice - may I?" "Yes, wallah!"
he said. "When you go north, go + see Mr Nalder
+ make friends with him; + especially settle that
little matter of loot which he reckons up against
your tribe. Will you?" "Yes" he said "if you'll
give me a word to Nalder to say I've talked to you."
- There! I don't know how much it will come to,
but it's an atmosphere, isn't it. That's why I've told
you the whole tale, + I've told it to Mr Nalder, briefly.
He will understand.
'Ajil came in to Faisal himself, but most of the down-
river shaikhs come in to us. They come to me, rather
anxious + say "Ought we to go + see
the Amir Title referring to Faysal. ?" And
I say" Not only you ought, but you must - hurry
off at once; + take this letter to Rustam Beg Haidar
in which I've told him what fine fellows you are +

4.
what good service you've done." They go.
That won't last + I don't want it to last. I shall
be glad when they go straight to Faisal + Sir Percy + I
drop out - that's the thing we're aiming at. Meantime,
that is the way it's done. The doing of it is uncommonly
absorbing, I find.
That evening I had got so tired of sitting in the office
that in spite of the heat I went out riding, + coming
home along the river bank for coolness, I passed
Faisal's new house, up stream - a house they have
rented for them him which is being done up. I saw his motor
at the door so I left my pony with one of his slaves
+ went up onto the roof where I found him sitting with
his
ADC aide-de-camp s. It was wonderful, the sun just set, the softly
luminous curves of the river below us, the belt of palm trees,
+ then the desert with 'Aqar Quf standing up against
the fading red of the sky. We all sat + talked. Faisal
uses no honorifics: " Enti, thou" he says to me - it's
so refreshing after the endless "honours" + "excellencies" -
"Enti 'Iraqiyah, enti badawiyah - you're a
Mesopotamian, a Beduin."
I dressed like lightning for an enormous dinner party
given by Mr Barrington Ward K. C. at
the Club Possibly the British, Railway or Alwiyah Social Club in Baghdad.
- 40 of
us + a burning wind in addition. I was happy
because I sat by Mr Thomson, + there were plenty of
people to talk to who didn't dance. I went away
at 11.30, after which, I understand, the fun began
but the hour of their fun is so closely connected with
the time I go into office that I don't often share in it.
Next evening Lady Cox,
the Slaters Mr and Mrs Slater, later divorced.
+ I + one or two more

went out to swim + dine - the place we swim is exactly opposite
Faisal's new house + as we landed, there was Faisal, trailing
over the sand in his long robes with his
ADC aide-de-camp s + Ja'far
looking incredibly huge in Arab dress. There wasn't room
for me to dress in the launch so I went up to a
familiar dressing room in the willows above the sand,
+ coming back barefoot was hailed to Faisal's
dinner, spread on the sand, where as they had all
taken off their kerchiefs +
abbas Loose over-garment.
I wasn't out
of place with bare feet + wet hair. We sat + talked
of 'Ajil, the
Shammar Tribe descended from the ancient Yemeni tribe of Tayy.
Shaikh, till the moon rose + it was time to
go back to my own dinner. And yesterday I had another Arab
dinner in my house, mostly official people up for the coronation
+ very nice except that the night was too hot. It continued
to be that - too hot for sleep - but there wasn't so much of
it for I got up at 4.30 + at 5.30 started on a picnic.
My party of guests were Faisal + his
ADC aide-de-camp s, the
GOC in C
General Officer Commanding in Chief , Colonel
Joyce, Ja'far + Nuri Sa'id the
C. G. S. Chief of the General Staff
of the Arab army.
Mr Slater started with us, with Mr Barrington Ward, but
they broke down en route owing to my having missed the
road + therefore taking them for a mile or two over
thorn-covered desert till we found it again. Faisal +
the
C in C. Commander in Chief , in whose motor I was, bore the bumping
with complete composure. We went to 'Aqar Quf - you
remember I once led you also astray going there; it seems
to be a habit. However we got there at 6.30, saw Aqar Quf -
it has the great merit as a ruin of there not being too
much to see! you can't be wearied by it. And the desert was
heavenly in the early morning. By the time we were ready,
Zaya had cleverly spread breakfast in the shadow of the
brick tower + we had a very cheerful meal, much enlivened
by the fact that the
C in C Commander in Chief
is the worst man at disposing
himself on the ground I ever saw. All the Arabs, including

5
Faisal, who sit cross-legged by nature, were exhilarated
to see how entirely his legs refused to double up, + he laughed
too. We struck the right road going home + got in
before 9.
Meantime - this is secret - there's a breeze on. The
Col. Colonial
Office has sent us a most red-tapy cable saying
that Faisal in his coronation speech must announce
that the ultimate authority in the land is the High
Commissioner. Faisal refuses + he is quite right. We
are going, as you know, to drop the mandate + enter into
treaty regulates relations with Mesopotamia. Faisal says
that from the first we must recognize that he is an
independent sovereign in treaty with us, otherwise he can't
hold his extremists. Sir Percy, bless him, wobbled a
little, but my view was that as it came to the same either
way, in the end, there was no point in claiming an authority
we could not enforce. We are not going to reconquer
Mesopotamia. Suppose Faisal is the final authority +
he refuses to accept the High Commissioner's advice,
what can the
H. C. High Commissioner
do? He can either persuade him,
or as a last resort he can say that he will resign
- "Yes" said Sir Percy, bettering it "+ the British
advisors + troops all retire to Basrah which will
be delighted to have us, leaving Baghdad + Mosul
to their fate." That's what the
H. C. High Commissioner
can say +
it's all he can say if he, not Faisal, is the ultimate
authority. We hold the trump cards + don't need to cheat. Faisal drafted an admirable statement
which was telegraphed home + Sir Percy a still
better which accompanied Faisal's.
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
had said
that, if Faisal didn't accept their view, the coronation must
be delayed. It is fixed for Tuesday, the day after
tomorrow, + the whole universe has assembled or is

assembling here for it. Sir Percy telegraphed firmly that
in his opinion it could not be delayed + it is going
on. We have got
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
in a cleft stick. If Faisal
were to resign, after our pressing him upon the country,
where should we be? Sir Percy would have to resign
too, for he could not possibly form another government
+ then where would
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
be? If the worst comes to
the worst (but I don't think it will) Faisal + Sir Percy
will go to London after the coronation to conclude
the treaty.
They don't understand, perhaps it can't be expected,
that we are not building here with lifeless stones; we're
encouraging the living thing to grow + we feel it
pulsing in our hands. We can direct it, to a great
extent, but we can't prevent its growing upwards.
That is, indeed, what we have invited it to do.
Darling goodbye. This is rather an interesting letter
I think. But upon my soul it is interesting being
at this job.
If I write too much about all the things I'm doing,
you understand that's only because I'm writing to
you + don't bother to put things indefinitely, as
you must to casual enquirers.
Ever your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude
I'm now going for our usual Sunday swim +
subsequent dinner on Mr Tod's steamer. About
14 of us go every Sunday evening. Could you send
me an india rubber filler for my pen? Mine has burst +

I ink my fingers dreadfully filling my
stylographic pen.

dated
21 August
1921
recd Received
24
Sep
September
1921
Sir Hugh Bell Bart C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
England
ARAB BUREAU,
BAGHDAD.
G L Bell
